title: 107_hr1085
content: The "Mining Claim Maintenance Act of 2001" is referred to as the general mining laws in title 30 of the United States Code. This Act establishes maintenance fees for mining claims. The "Mining Claim Maintenance Act of 2001" establishes a claim maintenance fee of $100 per unpatented mining claim, mill, or tunnel site to be paid annually to the Secretary of the Interior. This fee replaces the assessment work requirement under the general mining laws. Oil shale claims are exempt from this fee if a fee is already required under the Energy Policy Act of 1992. The Act establishes a claim maintenance fee for unpatented mining claims, with exceptions for certain cases. Claimants can waive the fee by meeting specific requirements, and those holding 10 or fewer mining claims can choose to perform assessment work instead of paying the fee. Claimants with 10 or fewer mining claims can avoid paying maintenance fees by meeting specific criteria related to production, exploration work, and surface disturbance. They also have the option to perform assessment work instead of paying the fee. Claimants with 10 or fewer mining claims can opt to perform assessment work instead of paying maintenance fees. They must meet filing requirements and certify the work by August 31 each year. Definitions include "related party" as spouse, dependent children, and those with control over the claimant. Control encompasses actual, legal, and the power to exercise control. Ownership of mining claims can be influenced through various means such as common directors, officers, stockholders, a voting trust, or a holding company. SEC. 102. LOCATION FEE. A $25.00 location fee per claim is required for new mining claims. SEC. 103. CO-OWNERSHIP. Annual claim maintenance fee replaces assessment requirements. SEC. 104. FAILURE TO PAY. Failure to pay fees results in forfeiture of claim. SEC. 105. OTHER REQUIREMENTS. The requirements of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 related to filings for claims and sites remain unchanged. Section 2324 of the Revised Statutes is amended to include waivers under the Mining Claim Maintenance Act of 2001. The Secretary of the Interior will adjust fees based on the Consumer Price Index every 5 years. The Secretary will adjust fees based on the Consumer Price Index every 5 years, or more frequently if deemed reasonable. Claimants will be notified of any adjustments by July 1, and the adjustment will apply starting the first assessment year after September 1. SEC. 106. REGULATIONS. The Secretary of the Interior will establish rules and regulations to implement this title promptly after its enactment. TITLE II--LIMITATION ON PATENTS SEC. 201. MINING CLAIMS SEC. 201 of TITLE II states that no patent for a mining claim will be issued unless specific requirements are met. If the Secretary approves, the claim holder is entitled to a patent as per pre-Act conditions. SEC. 202 discusses mill sites. SEC. 202 of TITLE II addresses mill sites, stating that no patent will be issued for any mill site claim unless specific requirements are met. If approved by the Secretary, the claim holder is entitled to a patent as per pre-Act conditions.
